stem: Dr. {{candidate_name}}, can you explain how a pulse oximeter works?

prompts.text: Describe the basic principles of pulse oximetry.
expectedKeyFacts: Uses spectrophotometry — absorption of light by haemoglobin
Two wavelengths: red (660 nm) and infrared (940 nm)
Oxyhaemoglobin absorbs more infrared, deoxyhaemoglobin absorbs more red
Light source (LED) on one side, photodetector on other
Measures pulsatile (arterial) component vs non-pulsatile (venous, tissue)
Ratio of red to infrared absorption calculates SpO₂
Calibrated using empirical data from healthy volunteers

prompts.text: Why does the pulse oximeter use two different wavelengths?
expectedKeyFacts: Oxyhaemoglobin and deoxyhaemoglobin have different absorption spectra
At 660 nm (red): deoxyhaemoglobin absorbs more than oxyhaemoglobin
At 940 nm (infrared): oxyhaemoglobin absorbs more than deoxyhaemoglobin
Isobestic point at 810 nm — both absorb equally
Ratio R = (AC red / DC red) / (AC infrared / DC infrared)
R value correlates with SpO₂ via calibration curve
When R = 1, SpO₂ ~85%

prompts.text: What factors can cause inaccurate pulse oximeter readings?
expectedKeyFacts: Poor perfusion: vasoconstriction, hypothermia, hypotension, cardiac arrest
Movement artifact: shivering, patient movement
Abnormal haemoglobins: carboxyhaemoglobin reads ~90%, methaemoglobin reads ~85%
Nail varnish, especially blue or black — absorbs red light
Ambient light interference
Skin pigmentation: may overestimate in dark skin when SaO₂ low
Venous pulsation: tricuspid regurgitation
Dyes: methylene blue, indocyanine green

prompts.text: A patient with carbon monoxide poisoning has an SpO₂ reading of 98%. Why is this misleading?
expectedKeyFacts: Carboxyhaemoglobin (COHb) absorbs light similarly to oxyhaemoglobin at 660 nm
Pulse oximeter cannot distinguish COHb from O₂Hb
Reads COHb as oxygenated — falsely high SpO₂
Typically reads ~90% regardless of true SaO₂
Patient may be severely hypoxic despite high SpO₂
Diagnosis requires co-oximetry (arterial blood gas)
Co-oximeter measures four haemoglobin species: O₂Hb, HHb, COHb, MetHb
Treatment: 100% oxygen (reduces COHb half-life from 5-6 hours to 1 hour)

prompts.text: How does the pulse oximeter differ from a co-oximeter?
expectedKeyFacts: Pulse oximeter: uses 2 wavelengths, estimates SaO₂ based on only O₂Hb and HHb
Co-oximeter: uses 4+ wavelengths, directly measures all haemoglobin species
Co-oximeter measures: O₂Hb, HHb, COHb, MetHb — reports fractional saturation
Pulse oximeter reports functional saturation: O₂Hb / (O₂Hb + HHb)
Co-oximeter more accurate in abnormal haemoglobins
Pulse oximeter non-invasive and continuous; co-oximeter requires blood sample
Pulse oximeter unreliable when dyshemoglobins present

rescuePrompt: Perhaps you could tell me what happens to the pulse oximeter reading in a patient with very poor peripheral perfusion — what would you see?
keyFacts: Spectrophotometry using red (660 nm) and infrared (940 nm) light
Oxyhaemoglobin absorbs more infrared, deoxyhaemoglobin absorbs more red
Errors: poor perfusion, movement, abnormal Hb, nail varnish, dyes
Co-oximeter uses 4+ wavelengths, measures all Hb species

scoringGuidance.pass: Explains spectrophotometry and two wavelengths, describes absorption differences between oxy/deoxyhaemoglobin, knows causes of inaccuracy including abnormal haemoglobins, explains CO poisoning paradox, distinguishes pulse oximeter from co-oximeter; stronger candidates discuss calibration curve and isobestic point
scoringGuidance.borderline: Knows pulse oximeter measures oxygen but mechanism unclear, mentions some error sources but missing key ones like COHb, vague on co-oximeter differences
scoringGuidance.fail: Cannot explain basic principle, does not understand two wavelengths or absorption spectra, unaware of limitations with abnormal haemoglobins, no knowledge of co-oximetry
